top_categories.workout_context: Trans Am Bike Race’s 4233-mile distance demands power production deep into fatigue — the defining challenge of ultra-distance gravel.

Trans Am Bike Race’s primarily paved roads following the historic transamerica bicycle trail and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Every session at Trans Am Bike Race intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Racing Trans Am Bike Race isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 4233 miles, Trans Am Bike Race rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Trans Am Bike Race when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Trans Am Bike Race’s paved roads (90%), gravel roads demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Trans Am Bike Race’s 175,000ft of climbing demands seated and standing versatility — the ability to change climbing style as gradient and fatigue dictate.
Trans Am Bike Race rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Trans Am Bike Race’s primarily paved roads following the historic transamerica bicycle trail delivers on race day.

Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Trans Am Bike Race — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on primarily paved roads following the historic transamerica bicycle trail.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Trans Am Bike Race. Make this intensity feel like home.

race_overlay.heat: June in Astoria, Oregon to Yorktown, Virginia — June start means variable spring weather across 4,200 miles. Oregon coast can be cool and foggy. Rockies may still have snow at Hoosier Pass (11,542ft). Kansas brings relentless wind and potential dust storms. Missouri/Kentucky humidity builds. Virginia's Appalachians are steep, hot, and humid. Temperature swings from 40s in mountains to 100°F+ in Kansas plains. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before Trans Am Bike Race — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day. Race-day realities: Virginia humidity and heat in June.
race_overlay.nutrition: Ultra-distance fueling for 4233 miles: 80–100g carbs/hour from mile 1 — don’t wait until you’re hungry. Practice your exact race-day nutrition in every long training ride. Carry backup calories. 4233 miles burns 8,000–12,000+ calories — you cannot replace them all, but you must try.
race_overlay.altitude: Trans Am Bike Race with 175,000ft of climbing, much of it above 8,000ft demands altitude preparation. Arrive 5–7 days early for acclimatization. Expect 5–15% power reduction at altitude. Increase iron intake 4 weeks out. Hydrate aggressively — altitude increases fluid loss by 20–40%.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Trans Am Bike Race requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on primarily paved roads following the historic transamerica bicycle trail to build confidence. Expect: paved roads (90%), gravel roads, bike paths.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, VO2max, and Endurance to prepare you for 4233 miles of primarily paved roads following the historic transamerica bicycle trail in Astoria, Oregon to Yorktown, Virginia.
